SUBORDINATE COURTS (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

     The Minister for Law (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, this Bill before the House seeks to amend the Subordinate Courts Act as part of a general plan to restructure the jurisdiction and powers of the courts in Singapore. Two other Bills have been approved by this House yesterday. This is the third Bill as part of the restructuring. Since certain provisions in this Bill are similar to the Bill approved yesterday to amend the Supreme Court of Judicature Act, I will not be dealing with such provisions.

Column: 131



    The civil jurisdiction of the District Court is at present limited to the following matters: First, monetary claims not exceeding $50,000 founded on contract or tort or under any written law; second, action for the recovery of immovable property where title is not in dispute; third, proceedings for the grant of probate and administration acts; fourth, proceedings for distress of rent; and fifth, interpleader proceedings.

    Sir, the law applicable to these proceedings constitutes actually a very small part of the civil law in Singapore. Most of the disputes in the proceedings turn on the facts and hardly involve any points of law, leave alone complicated points of law. As a result, the civil work of a District Judge does not really prepare him for hearing civil disputes in the High Court if eventually he should be appointed a Judge of the High Court.

    Clauses 5 and 9 increase the civil jurisdiction of a District Court to include the following matters: First, non-monetary claims founded on contract or tort; second, actions for the recovery of immovable property even where title is in dispute; and third, certain equity proceedings.

    Clause 2 increases the monetary limit of a District Court from $50,000 to $100,000 generally, and from $250,000 to $3 million for grant of probate and administration actions. Clause 14 provides that these limits may be amended from time to time, up or down, by the President after consulting the Chief Justice. The President has to act on the advice of the Cabinet before making such order. Under the existing provisions, the Subordinate Courts Act has to be amended in order to vary the monetary limits.

    The enlarged civil jurisdiction will enable District Judges to acquire a broader range of experience and a more extensive knowledge of the law.

    Clause 21 increases the jurisdiction of a Magistrate's Court from $10,000 to $30,000. But there is no increase in the subject jurisdiction of a Magistrate's Court.

Column: 132



    Finally, Sir, clause 22 empowers a Subordinate Court to refer any constitutional issue arising in an action before it to the High Court for determination. This is only right because a Subordinate Court is not the appropriate forum to determine such an issue. Provision is made for the Attorney-General to be heard on any such issue.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Bedok GRC): Sir, I shall be very brief. I rise to support the Bill.

    In this Bill, the civil jurisdictions of a District Court and a Magistrate's Court have been increased. This will result in improved efficiency in the administration of justice. The Government Parliamentary Committee welcomes the plan to restructure the courts.

    Sir, in particular, I welcome the new section 41A in clause 18 which provides that the Chief Justice may by order direct proceedings commenced in the District Court to be heard and determined by the High Court. This, in my mind, is a welcome safeguard to the system when we are investing enhanced responsibilities and powers to the District and Magistrate's Court.

     Mr Ho Peng Kee (Sembawang GRC): Sir, I speak in support of the Bill.

    The reorganisation of the Subordinate Courts flows from the restructuring of the Supreme Court. Now that the Judges and Magistrates of the Subordinate Courts have enlarged civil jurisdiction, it is imperative that more attention be focused on their training and development. This should be done in relation to both legal as well as other related skills and knowledge.

    Sir, two points should be considered. First, is there a need to raise the qualifying criterion before a person can be appointed as a judicial officer of the Subordinate Courts, especially in the case of Magistrates and Deputy Registrars? Currently, no qualifying period exists before which a

Column: 133

person can be appointed as Deputy Registrar. In the case of a Magistrate, a lawyer of more than a year's standing may be appointed -just one year.

    Some Singaporeans are surprised that some of our Deputy Registrars and Magistrates are relatively young. In these young hands lie the power to decide the commercial and personal fate of fellow Singaporeans. Dispensation of justice and application of the law do not take place in a vacuum but in the context of Singapore's social milieu. Not only is legal knowledge important but also wisdom that comes with experience in dealing with matters of the world.

    Second, is there a need to ensure that our Magistrates and Judges in the Subordinate Courts are better prepared to undertake their important tasks? Sir, may I offer three suggestions.

    First, a mentoring scheme - where new Judges and Magistrates are attached to more experienced ones to, in the first instance, understudy and observe and, on a continuing basis, to consult and discuss difficult points of law. In this way, new appointees can also cultivate that important X-factor - a judicial temperament.

    Second, structured in-house seminars where latest developments and emerging areas of the law can be fully ventilated and experience shared. NUS law staff can be enlisted for this purpose.

    Third, workshops to develop better interpersonal and communication skills. Judicial officers are figures of authority. In dispensing justice, they must be able to inspire confidence in the lawyers and clients with whom they deal. Observers in the gallery also form opinions of our judicial system from what they see. It can be an unnerving experience for young and new judicial officers to handle lawyers who are senior in age, experience and wisdom. It is easy to overlook this area which I feel is important.

    Sir, I believe that a loose version of these improvement schemes has been introduced in the Subordinate Courts. They should be better structured and

Column: 134

formalised. Some countries like Japan take the training of judges very seriously. And why not!

     Mr Chia Shi Teck (Nominated Member): Sir, I rise to support the Bill. Whilst I am no lawyer to go into the details of the qualifications of the District Judges, I would like to ask the Minister - with the passage of this Bill, the District Judges would have their civil jurisdiction increased to $100,000 - what percentage of the workload in the High Court will then be reduced and shifted to these District Courts and can the District Courts cope? Would that also mean there is no more need to appoint High Court Judges or there is no more need for additional Judicial Commissioners? Could the Minister also assure the House that there is no more need, as mentioned some years ago, for recruiting foreign judges in the High Court? Maybe the Minister could explain how these changes in the jurisdiction could bring about more efficiency as simply transferring the workload from the High Court to the District Judges may not just increase efficiency.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, I wish to thank the Members who have spoken. Dr Arthur Beng did not raise any specific points that require an answer. Mr Ho Peng Kee raised several points. Of course, on the question of qualifying criterion for Magistrates exercising civil jurisdiction, I have no doubt that the Chief Justice will look into this. Magistrates are appointed from legal officers with one to five years' experience, as far as I know, and no legal officer who has not undergone some period of induction is likely to be appointed a Magistrate. Most civil cases in the Magistrate's Court are in fact decided on facts. There is usually very little argument on issues of law and much less difficult issues of law.

    As for the mentor system, I understand that there has, in fact, been in place in the Subordinate Courts a mentor system for some years and I believe it is working well. I also understand that there is also in place a programme for training and continuing legal education for junior officers. For example, last week, they participated in a seminar on "Probation of

Column: 135

offenders". I was told that before that, they also attended a lecture on how to write judgments which was given by one of the more experienced judges, Mr L P Thean. But we must remember that the judiciary in both the High Court and the Subordinate Courts is actually quite small. I believe the Chief Justice is doing all that he can to ensure that our Magistrates and District Judges will have a sufficient knowledge of the law as well as communication skills and the factor of temperament referred to by Mr Ho Peng Kee. With all these skills, they would, in dispensing justice, inspire confidence in the lawyers and others appearing before them.

    Mr Chia Shi Teck asked for the percentage of the workload. I am afraid I do not have such data. It will ease the workload of the High Court to some extent but, as I mentioned, that is not the only objective. Does this mean that there will be no more need to appoint more High Court Judges? I do not think we should come to such a conclusion because the volume of work in the courts will always increase. If our economic growth is sustained, there will be more litigation and more cases will come up to the courts. And if we want to increase the extent to which we clear up the backlog, I am sure more Judges will be needed as time goes on.

    The Member referred to foreign Judges. I believe he was referring to a discussion which took place in this Chamber many years ago. I do not think the question

Column: 136

really arises now as to whether foreign Judges have to be appointed. The main question is: can we get Judges from Singaporeans or permanent residents who are familiar with our system, our laws, our aspirations and our goals, in other words, people who are familiar not only with the jurisprudence but also the values which are embedded in our corpus of jurisprudence. If we can get these people to come forth and take up judicial appointments either as permanent High Court Judges or as Judicial Commissioners, and if the Chief Justice is able to get them and persuade them and they are appointed, then I think this question of foreign Judges does not arise.

    Question put, and agreed to.

NATIONAL HERITAGE BOARD BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

     The Minister for Information and the Arts (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The National Heritage Board will enable the Government to better preserve and promote Singapore's heritage. The Board will be a one-stop resource centre bringing together the National Museum, the National Archives and the Oral History Department, the current heritage departments of the Ministry of the Information and the Arts.

    The National Heritage Board will explore and present the heritage and nationhood of the people of Singapore in the context of their ancestral cultures, their links with Southeast Asia, with Asia and with the world through the collection, preservation, interpretation and display of objects and records. It will also promote public awareness, appreciation and understanding of our past.

    As a statutory board, the National Heritage Board will enjoy flexibility in its operation and in recruiting, deploying and developing staff. There are also cost savings in integrating the three departments into a single organisation.

    Although the Government will fund the greater part of the development and recurrent costs of the National Heritage Board, it is very important that we also encourage members of the public, as corporations and as individuals, to give their full support. The Government has announced plans to expand the present National Museum and organise the exhibits into separate museums. The

Column: 138

Singapore Art Museum and the Asian Civilisations Museum and the History of Singapore Museum will be ready from 1995 onwards. We will provide ample scope for public participation. Collectors and well-wishers from Singapore and abroad will be encouraged to lend and donate their art collections.

    As a young nation, it will take us many generations to build up our national collection. Unlike countries like the UK and France, we have no imperial booty to draw upon. Happily, travelling exhibitions are easier to organise in the age of the jumbo jet. Thus, we have been able to put up world-class exhibitions on Imperial China at Empress Place. We recently signed an agreement to bring in exhibits from India, and I hope to sign similar agreements with the Turkish and the Egyptian Governments later this year. Next month, the National Museum will display 63 exquisite pieces from the Rockefeller Collection of the Asia Society. In this way, we supplement our own collection with loans from others.

    The various communities in Singapore should also participate in the effort to preserve our heritage. They are in a good position to collect, preserve and promote an awareness of their own heritage in a living way. As I announced last year, the Federation of Chinese Clans Association is interested to set up a Chinese Heritage Centre at the old Nantah Administration Building to research and present the heritage of the Chinese outside China, their migratory patterns and way of life and the way they have sunk roots in different countries and made contributions to local communities.

    The Malay community is now exploring the concept and feasibility of setting up a Malay Heritage Centre. The Government will make available the old Istana at Kampong Glam for this purpose at nominal rental. Likewise, the Government will provide similar assistance to the Indian and Eurasian communities.

    As I informed the House during the Committee of Supply, the Government

Column: 139

will help the four communities set up endowment funds to run these centres subject to a ceiling of $5 million for the Chinese, $2 million for the Malays, $1 million for the Indians and $1/4 million for the Eurasians on a dollar-for-dollar basis. For the Singapore History Museum, it will present Singapore's history in a national and international context. The community heritage centres can capture the social and cultural heritage of each community in greater depth and in a more particular way. These heritage centres will help Singaporeans anchor their cultural roots. In this way, we strike a balance between emphasising our unity and celebrating our diversity.

    The National Heritage Board will also work closely with the Singapore Heritage Society and other heritage organisations.

    The Government will give maximum autonomy to the National Heritage Board. The Board will formulate its own personnel policies so that the right people can be engaged, retained and developed. There is a shortage of trained and experienced heritage administrators in Singapore, a shortage that may hamper the development of our museums and archives. The National Heritage Board will help to build up such a core of heritage professionals.

    In addition to Government's financial support, the National Heritage Board will be free to raise its own revenue and receive donations in cash and in kind. All donations to the National Heritage Board will be tax-exempt. For donations to the National Museum, the Finance Minister has recently announced that double tax deduction will be allowed. The Board will also be free to acknowledge donors by naming rooms or wings in the various museums after them. The Board will also be able to form companies to undertake functions more effectively carried out on a commercial basis.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the National Heritage Board will comprise a Chairman, a Deputy

Column: 140

Chairman and 10 to 25 other members. The membership will be broad-based. We will have representatives from heritage organisations, the private sector and the public sector. We have to strike a balance between supporting heritage for heritage sake and getting value for money.

    To ensure that the National Heritage Board is well advised on methods pertaining to heritage in Singapore and elsewhere, the Bill enables the Board to form advisory committees. Their members need not and should not be confined to Singaporeans. We must look for foreigners who can help us. These committees will cover the major fields of museums, archives and oral history.

    The National Heritage Board will have powers similar to other statutory boards. Its specific powers include developing and managing museums, archives, oral history centres and other facilities. It will also be empowered to conduct archaeological investigations of land under development which the Board believes may contain artefacts of historical or heritage value. In exercising this power, the Board will be careful to minimise inconvenience to the owners of the affected premises.

    The National Heritage Board will absorb the present staff and properties of the National Museum, the National Archives and the Oral History Department. The National Heritage Board Bill provides for the repeal of the National Archives and Records Centre Act of 1967.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the purpose of our effort in heritage is to instil in all Singaporeans the sense that while we are a young nation, we are an ancient people.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

     Mr Ho Peng Kee (Sembawang GRC): Sir, I speak in support of the Bill.

    The integration of the National Museum, National Archives and Oral History Department is timely. Indeed, some will say it is overdue. It will provide

Column: 141

greater coherence and synergy to Government's efforts in ensuring that Singaporeans, particularly younger ones, remember and cherish our roots.

    Sir, an important result of the Bill is that more Singaporeans and foreigners with relevant expertise, as the Minister has mentioned just now, will have a say in how our heritage, both as Singaporeans and as members of different races with global links, is preserved, interpreted and presented. Heritage is never a top-down exercise. To invoke passion and a sense of belonging, involvement and identification are vital. This the Bill seeks to achieve.

    I hope Singaporeans will indeed feel this sense of passion in being involved and being identified with the cause underlying the Bill. We have heard from the Minister that the setting up of community heritage centres or museums is part of this overall approach. Each community is given the opportunity to share its heritage and culture with fellow Singaporeans, and it is a good thing that they themselves have a say on how this is to be done. In this way, greater awareness and pride are created in one's roots and culture. However, may I add a word of caution here. I hope this awareness and pride will not stop there. Awareness must cross the physical boundaries of one's own community museum to encompass the other community museums or centres of the other races. And more importantly, pride must not rest solely on one's own roots, but rise to a higher and common level, based on the fact that we are all Singaporeans. I hope parents will make the extra effort to bring their children to visit not only their own community museum, but also those of the other races and the Singapore History Museum.

    Schools and community groups can do likewise. Here, Sir, I would urge MITA to monitor the racial profile of visitors to each of these museums when they are set up and take appropriate steps should there be an imbalance.

    Sir, Singapore's heritage is also captured by several buildings and structures dotting the island. Examples are the

Column: 142

Ford Factory, St James Power Station and the Armenian Church. There are many other examples that I am sure Members know of. Each of them, Sir, has a story to tell. I would like to ask the Minister whether steps are being taken to ensure that these stories are told, again and again, to our children and their children.

    Finally, Sir, I think it is common experience that in many quizzes that are conducted in Singapore, participants seem to know more about world history and events than Singapore's history or events which impact on Singapore's major races. I hope this Bill will go some way to rectify this unfortunate situation.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Encik Yatiman Yusof): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the Bill.

    Mr Speaker, no society could be strong and resilient if it detaches itself from the past. A Spanish-born American philosopher, George Santayana, once said, "Progress, far from consisting in change, depends on retentiveness ... Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to fulfil it."

    Sir, for a country with a short history, such linkage to the past is a crucial factor in building the foundation for the future. It is an amalgam needed for the evolution of a great society.

    The setting up of the National Heritage Board with the objective of bringing the National Museum, the National Archives and Records Centre and the Oral History Department, therefore, must be seen in this context. After the setting up of the National Arts Council, the formation of the National Heritage Board is a logical step. The introduction of this Bill is. therefore, both timely and essential.

    Unlike my colleague who said that this is a bit too late, to me, Sir, the Bill is a first step that provides a seriously coordinated effort in proactively using the past to the optimum in educating the future generation of their past history and culture. In doing so, we are

Column: 143

also meeting the challenge of whether we have the wisdom to use wealth to enrich and elevate our national life and to advance our quality of civilization.

    We have committed ourselves into the Next Lap and our varied past that stemmed from the rich Chinese, Indian and Malay civilizations are assets to us. The setting up of this Board, therefore, should ensure that these multi-cultural aspects of Singapore are sufficiently projected and represented.

    Sir, sometime ago, I raised in this House the question of acquisition of our cultural artefacts which could possibly be buried in Singapore, its surrounding islands and seas, and the possibility of introducing laws to effect their acquisition. In this connection, I wish to thank the Minister for incorporating clauses under the Miscellaneous Provisions in clause 46 the power to achieve this aim. However, the element of compensation or compensations to those who suffer loss as a result of the acquisition work is not clearly stated.

    Another question that I would like to ask the Minister is: since the effort to preserve or redevelop certain places or locations with historical significance will also involve some degree of participation from the communities who had been part of the life of such places, I wonder whether their aspirations and participation are given sufficient consideration. As an example, when we decided to preserve the Kampong Glam area, whether we had made the effort to seek for the opinions or views of those people who are living in this area.

    Sir, I support the Bill.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang (Braddell Heights)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, now that we have made certain achievements in economic performance, we are beginning to spend some time and effort on cultural matters and development of the culture of Singapore. To preserve our cultural heritage is an effort in the spiritual

Column: 144

construction of Singapore. Therefore, I welcome the National Heritage Board Bill which seeks to set up a centralised coordinating statutory body for the preservation of our national heritage so that we will be better able to carry out the work of preserving our cultural heritage.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, as the Chinese saying goes, "to do a job well, we must have the good tools in hand." The National Heritage Board, when established, will be able to work towards the preservation of our cultural heritage and artefacts and create favourable conditions for this purpose.      The Minister for Education (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, having heard the detailed account from Dr Vasoo, I am wondering whether there is any need for me to say any more. But I do have to respond to Mr Chia's motion.

total gross misconduct which he had shown when he was found out for abusing his research grants.

When first confronted on 4th March 1993, Dr Chee's immediate and most telling reaction was not to dispute that it was misuse of his research funds but to claim that he had intended to make payment. In other words, he knew that he had to pay and that he had done wrong by charging the sums to his research account.

    Here we have a simple case of a lecturer who cheated the University by misusing funds intended for his own research. When caught, at first he admitted it, but then, instead of apologising and refunding the money, he tried to wriggle his way out by claiming that he was entitled to use his research funds because his wife's PhD thesis was relevant to his own research.

Column: 207

research funds for related research projects by anyone else, least of all his wife, unless there is a proper arrangement for research collaboration. Dr Chee's wife was not his research collaborator. Service, he could have asked for arbitration as provided for under clause 17 of the Agreement for Service with the University.     Sir, we achieve our reputation as a corruption-free administration because we set high standards of honesty and integrity. Where public money is involved, we cannot accept lower standards. The main point is that the PAP Government sets the tone of administration - one of high standards of integrity and corruption-free. Any misdeeds will be tackled.
